page.title: 08Medieval Kettlesing
page.content: The Kettlesing area was recorded "waste" in the original Domesday Book, mainly due to the devestation of the North by William the Conqueror. It is probable that peasant labour would have been moved from upland manors to the devestated, yet still fertile, lowland demesnes of the Vale of York. In early medieval times the area became part of the royal hunting For- est of Knaresborough, and experienced relative prosperity until the ravages of the Black Death led to severe depopulation (estimate 40%) causing the adoption of less labour-intensive farming methods, particularly sheep- farming. It is probable that popula- tion figures did not regain their pre- Black Death levels for over 400 years.
